2008-02-05.snippet: UNITED ADDS A CHECKED-BAG FEE Saying that it was offering customers a “new, simplified checked-bag policy,” United Airlines said that it would charge $25 to check a second bag, starting May 5, for customers who travel domestically on advance p...
2008-02-05.lead_paragraph: UNITED ADDS A CHECKED-BAG FEE Saying that it was offering customers a “new, simplified checked-bag policy,” United Airlines said that it would charge $25 to check a second bag, starting May 5, for customers who travel domestically on advance purchase nonrefundable fares. The vast majority of coach passengers buy such fares, as opposed to the more expensive, fully refundable walk-up fares. United said the fee would generate more than $100 million a year “in cost savings and new revenue.” Most competitors allow coach passengers to check a second bag without charge. United’s fee policy also applies to travel to and from Canada; San Juan, P.R.; and St. Thomas, V.I., for tickets purchased starting this week. Passengers with Premier status or higher in United’s Mileage Plus frequent-flier program and those with Silver status or higher in the Star Alliance program will be exempt from the fee.

headline.main: Memo Pad: United Adds a Checked-Bag Fee

2008-02-12.snippet: LAST YEAR’S DELAYS Last year was the second worst ever for airline delays, with 73.4 percent of flights arriving on time, according to the United States Bureau of Transportation Statistics. Only in 2000 did the domestic airline industry post a w...
2008-02-12.lead_paragraph: LAST YEAR’S DELAYS Last year was the second worst ever for airline delays, with 73.4 percent of flights arriving on time, according to the United States Bureau of Transportation Statistics. Only in 2000 did the domestic airline industry post a worse record, with 72.59 percent of flights on time. Meanwhile, major domestic airlines continue to reduce the number of domestic seats they are putting into the skies, as measured by a metric called available seat miles. In January, United Airlines had 10.7 percent fewer available seat miles than in the previous January. For other airlines these are the figures: US Air, minus 5.4 percent; Delta and Northwest, each minus 4.4 percent; Continental, minus 2.7 percent; and American, minus 1.5 percent. But Southwest Airlines bolstered its January capacity by 5.3 percent.
